About Me

I'm a multidisciplinary engineer with experience at an IoT startup, industrial agriculture, and academic research. My experiences have exposed me to a spectrum of engineering challenges ranging from troubleshooting mechatronic heavy equipment prototypes to designing a high precision microscopy imaging system. My design experience and first principals engineering knowledge has prepared me well to navigate through the weeds of existing and hypothesized electrical, mechanical, and software systems.

Tree Imaging Machine

For the last 5 years on and off I’ve been involved with the Temporal Ecology Lab at UBC. To explore her new research hypotheses, my Principal Investigator (PI) needed to acquire a machine to take scans of their tree samples and wondered if I could make it for her. While some solutions exist, none had the capabilities she was hoping for. And the implementations vary in cost from $30,000 USD to $70,0000 USD. I bridged this gap by taking inspiration from existing solutions while adding features and operational improvements along the way. Excluding labor, my implementation can be recreated for under $3,500 CAD. At its core, this project is an open-source and open-hardware machine to take a grid of microscopic images and stitch them into one mosaic, producing a digital twin of tree cross sections. This project is my current brain baby, having created the feasibility and price estimates, developed the machine design, sourced required materials, as well as designed the software architecture, machine control, and 3D models. I’m also in the process of drafting a paper to publish in an academic journal and will be published as first author, hopefully in the coming months.

angular mongo typscript node

FPGA Deep Learning Hardware Accelerator

The MNIST Handwritten Digits dataset is a very common dataset used to train machine learning models to translate handwritten digits to integers. While there are many examples online showing how to train a model to find a neural networks weights, less explain how to deploy the weights to get inference from a model. Even less are descriptions of how to decrease the time to inference using FPGA's. This project aimed to deploy a Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) neural network (NN) on a DE1-SoC FPGA development board and perform hardware accelerated tasks to speed up the algorithm. The NN model was trained on the classic MNIST handwritten dataset and can classify the images into integers from 0 to 9. Custom Verilog hardware modules were written and were connected to a softcore NIOS II CPU. These hardware modules were memory-mapped and controlled by the CPU to perform hardware accelerated dot product calculations and direct memory access.

FPGA Verilog Neural Networks Hardware Acceleration

Perception for Robotic Arm

For my 4th year Integrated Engineering Capstone, I was responsible for the perception of a robotic arm used to sort McDonald's trash from a tray. Our team's goal was to identify waste on top of a tray, classify if the trash should be recycled, composted, or trashed, and move the item to the correct bin using a robotic arm. While I was involved in the discussions of other subsystems, my focus was on perceiving the waste in the robotics system.

To do this on a student team's budget, we purchased an XBOX Kinect V2 sensor to capture Red, Green, Blue, and Depth (RGBD) images. From there, I designed a data processing pipeline in Robot Operating System. This process primarily needed to accomplish two tasks. First, the classification of an object using a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) object classifier. Second, find the waste's centroid to inform the robotic arm where it needed to move to pick up the waste.

The hardest problem in this pipeline was developing a method to connect the category of waste from the CNN to the 3D representation of the waste. The most robust method I came up with was to encode unique RGB color arrays with a specific waste classification. By using a color encoding, I was able to cast the bounding box of an object classifier with its filled waste encoding onto a point cloud using colour image registration. This allowed for any downstream processing of a point cloud to automatically carry it's waste classification and minimize processing power to remember specific object instances.

ROS C++ Robotics PCL

3D Printed Flying Seed

A colleague of mine was hosting an event at the Botanical Gardens in Basel, Switzerland. As a fun interactive toy for the audience, he thought it would be great to have a model Dipterocarpus seed. Dipterocarpus seeds are notorious for their spiral descents while falling from their tree. I was fully on board with making this dream a reality, and with a few iterations I was able to make a simple and replicable model for him to print and display. He mustered together a big fan for people to launch the seeds in the air as well as made some custom stringed displays to suspend some models in the air.

FDM 3D Printing Biomimicry

Dendrometer Sensor Bracket Upgrade

One of the research questions of the Temporal Ecology Lab requires the use of dendrometer sensors. These dendrometers measure the diameter of a tree at various times throughout the day to show the daily variation. These sensors use a magnet and an IC to calculate this metric and heavily rely on the magnet's orientation. The original design uses one spring in the middle of bracket. If bumped, the magnet is no longer aligned to the measurement circuit and ruins the data.

The designers of this sensor fixed this problem in an updated version by adding two more springs which automatically aligned the magnetics orientation to the IC. The problem is that we didn't have the budget to invest $18,000 in 75 new sensors. I noticed that this fix could be added without the need for an entire new frame. I made a two piece bracket to add 2 more springs to the system, ordered the necessary springs and hardware, and assembled the upgrades. Since installing, we noticed a large improvement in data quality for $500 in parts instead of $18,000.

FDM 3D Printing Upgrade
